children.comment: Everything in Dart is an [Object].
children.name: Object

children.comment:
The equality operator.

The default behavior for all [Object]s is to return true if and
only if [:this:] and [other] are the same object.

If a subclass overrides the equality operator it should override
the [hashCode] method as well to maintain consistency.
Returns a string representation of this object.
children.name: toString

children.comment:
[noSuchMethod] is invoked when users invoke a non-existant method
on an object. The name of the method and the arguments of the
invocation are passed to [noSuchMethod] in an [Invocation].
If [noSuchMethod] returns a value, that value becomes the result of
the original invocation.

The default behavior of [noSuchMethod] is to throw a
[noSuchMethodError].
children.name: noSuchMethod

children.comment:
Get a hash code for this object.

All objects have hash codes. Hash codes are guaranteed to be the
same for objects that are equal when compared using the equality
operator [:==:]. Other than that there are no guarantees about
the hash codes. They will not be consistent between runs and
there are no distribution guarantees.

If a subclass overrides [hashCode] it should override the
equality operator as well to maintain consistency.
children.name: hashCode

children.comment: A representation of the runtime type of the object.
children.name: runtimeType

children.comment:
Creates a new [Object] instance.

[Object] instances have no meaningful state, and are only useful
through their identity. An [Object] instance is equal to itself
only.
children.name: Object

children.comment:
The primary instance for the framework. It contains all the managers.

You must use this to create, delete and retrieve entities.

It is also important to set the delta each game loop iteration, and initialize before game loop.
children.name: World

children.comment:
Makes sure all managers systems are initialized in the order they were
added.
children.name: initialize

children.comment:
Add a manager into this world. It can be retrieved later. World will
notify this manager of changes to entity.
children.name: addManager

children.comment: Returns a [Manager] of the specified [managerType].
children.name: getManager

children.comment: Deletes the manager from this world.
children.name: deleteManager

children.comment: Create and return a new or reused [Entity] instance.
children.name: createEntity

children.comment: Get an [Entity] having the specified [entityId].
children.name: getEntity

children.comment:
Adds a system to this world that will be processed by World.process().
If [passive] is set to true the system will not be processed by the world.
children.name: addSystem

children.comment: Removed the specified system from the world.
children.name: deleteSystem

children.comment: Retrieve a system for specified system type.
children.name: getSystem

children.comment: Performs an action on each entity.
children.name: _check

children.comment: Processes all changes to entities and executes all non-passive systems.
children.name: process

children.comment: Processes all changes to entities.
children.name: processEntityChanges

children.comment:
Removes all entities from the world.

Every entity and component has to be created anew. Make sure not to reuse
[Component]s that were added to an [Entity] and referenced in you code
because they will be added to a free list and might be overwritten once a
new [Component] of that type is created.
children.name: deleteAllEntities

children.comment: Adds a [Entity e] to this world.
children.name: addEntity

children.comment:
Ensure all systems are notified of changes to this [Entity e]. If you're
adding a [Component] to an [Entity] after it's been added to the world, then
you need to invoke this method.
children.name: changedEntity

children.comment: Delete the [Entity e] from the world.
children.name: deleteEntity

children.comment:
(Re)enable the [Entity e] in the world, after it having being disabled. Won't
do anything unless it was already disabled.
children.name: enable

children.comment:
Disable the [Entity e] from being processed. Won't delete it, it will
continue to exist but won't get processed.
children.name: disable

children.comment:
Returns a manager that takes care of all the entities in the world.
entities of this world.
children.name: entityManager

children.comment: Returns a manager that takes care of all the components in the world.
children.name: componentManager

children.comment: Gives you all the systems in this world for possible iteration.
children.name: systems

children.comment:
Use this class together with PlayerManager.

You may sometimes want to create teams in your game, so that
some players are team mates.

A player can only belong to a single team.
children.name: TeamManager

children.comment:
If you need to tag any entity, use this. A typical usage would be to tag
entities such as "PLAYER", "BOSS" or something that is very unique.
An [Entity] can only belong to one tag (0,1) at a time.
children.name: TagManager

children.comment:
You may sometimes want to specify to which player an entity belongs to.

An entity can only belong to a single player at a time.
children.name: PlayerManager

children.comment:
If you need to group your entities together, e.g. tanks going into "units" group or explosions into "effects",
then use this manager. You must retrieve it using world instance.

An [Entity] can only belong to several groups (0,n) at a time.
children.name: GroupManager

children.comment: Set the group of the entity.
children.name: add

children.comment: Remove the entity from the specified group.
children.name: remove

children.comment: Get all entities that belong to the provided group.
children.name: getEntities

children.comment: Returns the groups the entity belongs to, null if none.
children.name: getGroups

children.comment: Checks if the entity belongs to any group.
children.name: isInAnyGroup

children.comment: Check if the entity is in the supplied group.
children.name: isInGroup

children.comment: Manager.
children.name: Manager

children.comment:
This system has an empty aspect so it processes no entities, but it still gets invoked.
You can use this system if you need to execute some game logic and not have to concern
yourself about aspects or entities.
children.name: VoidEntitySystem

children.comment:
If you need to process entities at a certain interval then use this.
A typical usage would be to regenerate ammo or health at certain intervals, no need
to do that every game loop, but perhaps every 100 ms. or every second.
children.name: IntervalEntityProcessingSystem

children.comment: Process an [entity] this system is interested in.
children.name: processEntity

children.comment: Create a new [IntervalEntityProcessingSystem]. It requires at least one component.
children.name: IntervalEntityProcessingSystem

children.comment:
A system that processes entities at a interval in milliseconds.
A typical usage would be a collision system or physics system.
children.name: IntervalEntitySystem

children.comment:
Resets the accumulated delta to 0.

Call `super.end()` if you overwrite this function.
children.name: end

children.comment: Returns the accumulated delta since the system was last invoked.
children.name: delta

children.comment:
The purpose of this class is to allow systems to execute at varying intervals.

An example system would be an ExpirationSystem, that deletes entities after a certain
lifetime. Instead of running a system that decrements a timeLeft value for each
entity, you can simply use this system to execute in a future at a time of the shortest
lived entity, and then reset the system to run at a time in a future at a time of the
shortest lived entity, etc.

Another example system would be an AnimationSystem. You know when you have to animate
a certain entity, e.g. in 300 milliseconds. So you can set the system to run in 300 ms.
to perform the animation.

This will save CPU cycles in some scenarios.

Implementation notes:
In order to start the system you need to override the inserted(Entity e) method,
look up the delay time from that entity and offer it to the system by using the
offerDelay(num delay) method.
Also, when processing the entities you must also call offerDelay(num delay)
for all valid entities.
children.name: DelayedEntityProcessingSystem

children.comment: Return the delay until this entity should be processed.
children.name: getRemainingDelay

children.comment:
Process a entity this system is interested in. Substract the accumulatedDelta
from the entities defined delay.
children.name: processDelta

children.comment:
Start processing of entities after a certain amount of delta time.

Cancels current delayed run and starts a new one.
children.name: restart

children.comment:
Restarts the system only if the delay offered is shorter than the
time that the system is currently scheduled to execute at.

If the system is already stopped (not running) then the offered
delay will be used to restart the system with no matter its value.

If the system is already counting down, and the offered delay is
larger than the time remaining, the system will ignore it. If the
offered delay is shorter than the time remaining, the system will
restart itself to run at the offered delay.
children.name: offerDelay

children.comment: Get the initial delay that the system was ordered to process entities after.
children.name: getInitialTimeDelay

children.comment:
Get the time until the system is scheduled to run at.
Returns zero (0) if the system is not running.
Use isRunning() before checking this value.
children.name: getRemainingTimeUntilProcessing

children.comment:
Stops the system from running, aborts current countdown.
Call offerDelay or restart to run it again.
children.name: stop

children.comment: Check if the system is counting down towards processing.
children.name: running

children.comment:
A typical entity system. Use this when you need to process entities possessing the
provided component types.
children.name: EntityProcessingSystem

children.comment: Process a [entity] this system is interested in.
children.name: processEntity

children.comment: Create a new [EntityProcessingSystem]. It requires at least one component.
children.name: EntityProcessingSystem

children.comment:
The most raw entity system. It should not typically be used, but you can create your own
entity system handling by extending this. It is recommended that you use the other provided
entity system implementations.

There is no need to ever call any other method than process on objects of this class.
children.name: EntitySystem

children.comment: Called before processing of entities begins.
children.name: begin

children.comment: This is the only method that is supposed to be called from outside the library,
children.name: process

children.comment: Called after the processing of entities ends.
children.name: end

children.comment:
Any implementing entity system must implement this method and the logic
to process the given [entities] of the system.
children.name: processEntities

children.comment: Returns true if the system should be processed, false if not.
children.name: checkProcessing

children.comment: Override to implement code that gets executed when systems are initialized.
children.name: initialize

children.comment: Called if the system has received an [entity] it is interested in, e.g. created or a component was added to it.
children.name: inserted

children.comment: Called if an [entity] was removed from this system, e.g. deleted or had one of it's components removed.
children.name: removed

children.comment: Used only internally to generate distinct ids for entities and reuse them.
children.name: _IdentifierPool

children.comment:
Check if this entity is active.
Active means the entity is being actively processed.
children.name: isActive

children.comment: Check if the specified entityId is enabled.
children.name: isEnabled

children.comment: Get a entity with this id.
children.name: _getEntity

children.comment: Get how many entities are active in this world.
children.name: activeEntityCount

children.comment:
Get how many entities have been created in the world since start.
Note: A created entity may not have been added to the world, thus
created count is always equal or larger than added count.
children.name: totalCreated

children.comment: Get how many entities have been added to the world since start.
children.name: totalAdded

children.comment: Get how many entities have been deleted from the world since start.
children.name: totalDeleted

children.comment:
The entity class. Cannot be instantiated outside the framework, you must
create new entities using World.
children.name: Entity

children.comment: Add a [component] to this entity.
children.name: addComponent

children.comment: Removes the [Component] of [Type] [componentType] from this entity.
children.name: removeComponent

children.comment: Faster removal of components by [type] from a entity.
children.name: removeComponentByType

children.comment:
This is the preferred method to use when retrieving a [Component] from an
entity. It will provide good performance. The recommended way to retrieve
components from an entity is using the [ComponentMapper].

In order to retrieve the component fast you must provide a [ComponentType]
instance for the expected component.

Returns the [Component].
children.name: getComponent

children.comment:
Slower retrieval of a [Component] from this entity. Minimize usage of this,
but is fine to use e.g. when creating new entities and setting data in
components.

Returns [:null:] if none is found.
children.name: getComponentByClass

children.comment: Get all components belonging to this entity.
children.name: getComponents

children.comment: Adds this entity to the world.
children.name: addToWorld

children.comment:
Deletes this entity from the world.

The entity will be removed once world.process or world.processEntityChanges
has been called.
children.name: deleteFromWorld

children.comment: Disables this entity in the world.
children.name: disable

children.comment: Notifies the world that this entity has changed.
children.name: changedInWorld

children.comment: Enables this entity in the world.
children.name: enable

children.comment:
Get the unique ID of this entity. Because entity instances are reused
internally use this to identify between different instances.
children.name: uniqueId

children.comment:
Checks if the entity has been deleted from somewhere.
Returns [:true:] if it's active.
children.name: active

children.comment:
The internal id for this entity within the framework. No other entity will
have the same ID, but ID's are however reused so another entity may acquire
this ID if the previous entity was deleted.
children.name: id

children.comment:
An Aspect is used by systems as a matcher against entities, to check if a system is
interested in an entity. Aspects define what sort of component types an entity must
possess, or not possess.

This creates an aspect where an entity must possess A and B and C:
    Aspect.getAspectForAllOf([A, B, C])

This creates an aspect where an entity must possess A and B and C, but must not possess U or V.
    Aspect.getAspectForAllOf([A, B, C]).exclude([U, V])

This creates an aspect where an entity must possess A and B and C, but must not possess U or V, but must possess one of X or Y or Z.
    Aspect.getAspectForAllOf([A, B, C]).exclude([U, V]).oneOf([X, Y, Z])

You can create and compose aspects in many ways:
    Aspect.getEmpty().oneOf([X, Y, Z]).allOf([A, B, C]).exclude([U, V])
is the same as:
    Aspect.getAspectForAllOf([A, B, C]).exclude([U, V]).oneOf([X, Y, Z])
children.name: Aspect

children.comment: Returns an aspect where an entity must possess all of the specified components.
children.name: allOf

children.comment:
Excludes all of the specified components from the aspect. A system will not be
interested in an entity that possesses one of the specified excluded components.

Returns an aspect that can be matched against entities.
children.name: exclude

children.comment: Returns an aspect where an entity must possess one of the specified components.
children.name: oneOf

children.comment: Creates an aspect where an entity must possess all of the specified components.
children.name: getAspectForAllOf

children.comment: Creates an aspect where an entity must possess one of the specified componens.
children.name: getAspectForOneOf

children.comment:
Creates and returns an empty aspect. This can be used if you want a system that processes no entities, but
still gets invoked. Typical usages is when you need to create special purpose systems for debug rendering,
like rendering FPS, how many entities are active in the world, etc.

You can also use the all, one and exclude methods on this aspect, so if you wanted to create a system that
processes only entities possessing just one of the components A or B or C, then you can do:
Aspect.getEmpty().one("A", "B", "C");

Returns an empty Aspect that will reject all entities.
children.name: getEmpty

children.comment:
High performance component retrieval from entities. Use this wherever you need
to retrieve components from entities often and fast.
children.name: ComponentMapper

children.comment:
Fast but unsafe retrieval of a component for this entity.
No bounding checks, so this could throw an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsExeption,
however in most scenarios you already know the entity possesses this component.
children.name: get

children.comment:
Fast and safe retrieval of a component for this entity.
If the entity does not have this component then null is returned.
children.name: getSafe

children.comment: Checks if the entity has this type of component.
children.name: has

children.comment:
All components that should be managed in a [ObjectPool] must extend this class
and have a factory constructor that calls `new Poolable.of(...)` to create
a component. By doing so, dartemis can handle the construction of
[ComponentPoolable]s and reuse them when they are no longer needed.
children.name: ComponentPoolable

children.comment:
If you need to do some cleanup when removing this component override this
method.
children.name: cleanUp

children.comment:
All components extend from this class.

If you want to use a poolable component that will be added to a FreeList when
it is being removed use [ComponentPoolable] instead.
children.name: Component

children.comment: Does nothing in [Component], only relevant for [ComponentPoolable].
children.name: _removed

children.comment:
Objects of this class can be pooled in the [ObjectPool] for later reuse.

Should be added as a mixin.
children.name: Poolable

children.comment:
If you need to do some cleanup before this object moves into the Pool of
reusable objects.
children.name: cleanUp

children.comment: Calls the cleanup function and moves this object to the [ObjectPool].
children.name: moveToPool

children.comment:
Creates a new [Poolable] of [Type] [type].

The instance created with [createPoolable] should be created with
a zero-argument contructor because it will only be called once. All fields
of the created object should be set in the calling factory constructor.
children.name: Poolable.of

children.comment: Create a [Poolable] object with a zero argument constructor.
children.name: CreatePoolable

children.comment:
Inspired by <http://dartgamedevs.org/blog/2012/11/02/Free-Lists-For-Predictable-Game-Performance/>
this class stores objects that are no longer used in the game for later reuse.
children.name: ObjectPool

children.comment:
Returns a pooled object of [Type] [type]. If there is no object in the pool
it will create a new one using [createPoolable].
children.name: get

children.comment: Adds a [poolable] to the [ObjectPool].
children.name: add

children.comment: Add a specific [amount] of [Poolable]s for later reuse.
children.name: addMany

children.comment:
Math.sin() is slow. Using a lookup table for sin/cos is roughly 50x faster.
The loss of accuracy is minimal, maximum error is roughly 0,001.
You can probably get away with it.

Thanks to [Riven](http://riven8192.blogspot.com/2009/08/fastmath-sincos-lookup-tables.html "FastMath :: sin/cos lookup")
children.name: _TrigUtil

children.comment: A [ReadOnlyBag] offers a read-only view for an underlying [Bag].
children.name: ReadOnlyBag

children.comment: Returns the element at [index].
Returns [:true:] if the underlying [Bag] contains the [element].
children.name: contains

children.comment: Applies the function [f] to each element the underlying [Bag].
children.name: forEach

children.comment: Returns the size of the underlying [Bag].
children.name: size

children.comment: Returns [:true:] if the underlying [Bag] is empty.
children.name: isEmpty

children.comment: Using these function will save you some time if you are doing A LOT of calculation.
children.name: FastMath

children.comment:
Collection type a bit like List but does not preserve the order of its
entities, speedwise it is very good, especially suited for games.
children.name: Bag

children.comment: Returns the element at the specified [index] in the bag.

Applies the function [f] to each element of this collection.

Do not pass functions that add or remove elements because the order of
elements is not preserved and such a function could lead to unexpected
results.
children.name: forEach

children.comment:
Removes the element at the specified [index] in this bag. Does this by
overwriting with the last element and then removing the last element.
children.name: removeAt

children.comment: Remove and return the last object in the bag.
children.name: removeLast

children.comment:
Removes the first occurrence of the specified element from this bag, if
it is present. If the Bag does not contain the element, it is unchanged.
Does this by overwriting with the last element and then removing the last
element.
Returns [:true:] if this list contained the specified [element].
children.name: remove

children.comment: Returns [:true:] if this bag contains the [element].
children.name: contains

children.comment:
Removes from this Bag all of its elements that are contained in the
specified [bag].

Returns [:true:] if this Bag changed as a result of the call
children.name: removeAll

children.comment:
Adds the specified [element] to the end of this bag. If needed also
increases the capacity of the bag.
children.name: add

children.comment: Sets [element] at specified [index] in the bag.

Removes all of the elements from this bag. The bag will be empty after
this call returns.
children.name: clear

children.comment: Add all [items] into this bag.
children.name: addAll

children.comment: Returns the number of elements in this bag.
children.name: size

children.comment: Returns a read only view for this bag.
children.name: readOnly

children.comment: Returns [:true:] if this list contains no elements.
children.name: isEmpty

children.comment: Returns the number of elements the bag can hold without growing.
children.name: capacity

children.comment: Creates a new [Bag] with the elements of [iterable].
children.name: Bag.from
